attributes.title: What is the effect of education-based interventions in adult Chinese cardiac patients on disease-related knowledge, behaviours, and clinical outcomes?
attributes.description: This is registration of a protocol submitted to PROSPERO on March 9, 2020 before commencement of data extraction.

summary.value: This is registration of a protocol submitted to PROSPERO on March 9, 2020 before commencement of data extraction.

registration_responses.summary: This is registration of a protocol submitted to PROSPERO on March 9, 2020 before commencement of data extraction.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will advertise this “time 2” survey on MTurk to all of the 2,000 workers who participated in the “time 1” survey. Our sample size will be the number of workers who complete this “time 2” survey within a 2-week period.

analyses.value: We will conduct 3 separate paired t-tests, comparing participants’ scores on our 3 outcomes—political ideology, gender role conformity, and endorsement of gender stereotypes—at time 2 versus time 1. To test whether effects are moderated by participants’ levels of concern with the coronavirus pandemic, we will conduct 3 separate mixed ANOVAs, one for each outcome; in each ANOVA, the within-subjects factor will be time (time 1 vs. time 2) and the between-subjects factor level of pandemic concern (low vs. high). If an interaction effect between time and concern is significant, then we will follow up by conducting simple main effects of time within each level of concern. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they fail an attention check in this “time 2” survey or if they failed an attention check in the “time 1” survey. Participants who report a non-binary gender identity status will be excluded from the gender role conformity analyses.

dependent.value:
Dependent variables include political ideology, gender role conformity, and endorsement of gender stereotypes.

Political ideology will be assessed by the following question: “On the following scale from 1 (very liberal) to 7 (very conservative), how would you rate your political views?”

Gender role conformity will be assessed by Kachel et al.’s (2016) traditional masculinity/femininity scale, which is comprised of the following 6 items: “I consider myself as…” “Ideally, I would like to be…” “Traditionally, my interests would be considered as…” “Traditionally, my attitudes and beliefs would be considered as…” “Traditionally, my behavior would be considered as…” and “Traditionally, my outer appearance would be considered as…” Responses will range from 1 (very feminine) to 7 (very masculine). This variable will be reverse-scored for women so that higher scores reflect greater alignment with gender roles for one’s own gender for all participants (i.e., higher femininity for women, higher masculinity for men).

Endorsement of prescriptive gender stereotypes will be assessed by 8 items, with 4 items assessing attitudes toward women and 4 items assessing attitudes toward men. For attitudes toward women, the scale will lead with the following prompt: “Compared to men, women are expected to be more…” and will follow with 4 items on separate lines below, each presenting a Likert-type from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree): “clean,” “hygienic,” “sanitary,” and “pristine.” For attitudes toward men, the scale will lead with the following prompt: “Compared to women, men are expected to be more…” and will follow with 4 items on separate lines below, each presenting a Likert-type from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree): “risk-taking,” “brave,” “courageous,” and “adventurous.”

A moderator variable will be the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic. This will be assessed by the question, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses including “not at all,” “somewhat concerned,” “very concerned,” and “extremely concerned.” Participants who indicate that they are either “not at all” or “somewhat concerned” will be categorized as low in concern, whereas participants who indicate that they are either “very concerned” or “extremely concerned” will be categorized as high in concern.

conditions.value: There are no conditions in this survey; all participants will complete the same survey.

hypothesis.value: The present study will be a “time 2” assessment for a larger longitudinal study. Thus, all participants will have participated in the “time 1” study, in which we assessed political ideology, gender role conformity, and gender stereotypes. We will test whether people’s scores on these variables changed with the development of the coronavirus pandemic. We hypothesize that, compared to before the pandemic (time 1), after the start of the pandemic (time 2), people will report more conservative political ideology, more gender role conformity, and stronger gender stereotypes. We hypothesize that these effects will be moderated by the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic, being larger for participants who are high in concern than for participants who are low in concern.

attributes.title: National CPG on spinal injuries: a scoping review
attributes.description: A scoping review to systematically collect and chart the contents and methodologies of Russian national clinical practice guidelines on the management of spinal injuries. Background: In Russia, all existing national clinical practice guidelines are set by federal regulations for update and federal government approval until December 31, 2021. National guidelines on spine trauma were last published in 2016. No more recent major guidance on the management of spinal injuries for Russian-speaking orthopedic and neurosurgeons is known to date, although multiple separate guidelines on various aspects of the subject have been published elsewhere. However, no previous research has been undertaken to identify or summarize the existing guidance.

comments.value:
By the moment of this registration, the initial searches, study selection, and data review have been conducted on April 4-6, 2018. The eligibility criteria, the information sources, and the search strategy had been defined a priori on April 3, 2018. All of the above are available from the interim report on October 17, 2018 (in Russian) as attached.

Only a preliminary analysis was performed at that time, and it did not involve any formal data charting, transformation, comparison, or critical appraisal. This analysis was reported at several national conferences, notably the following:

* 11th Russian National Congress of Orthopaedic Surgeons, April 11-13, 2018; [the section program is available online (in Russian)](http://atorcongress.ru/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Хирургическая-вертебрология.pdf); also, please find the section program and the presentation slides attached.
* 8th Russian National Congress of Neurosurgeons, September 18-22, 2018; [the program is available online (in Russian)](http://zdrav.spb.ru/media/filebrowser/программа_съезда_нейрохирургов_18-22.09.2018.pdf); also, please find the program and the presentation slides attached.

On April 3-8, 2020, a formal data charting/critical appraisal form has been developed, and the charting/critical appraisal process has started with a formal analysis to follow. The initial sources of evidence are being reused. However, the searches are to be updated, and any new sources of evidence added.

A PRISMA-P/ScR-compliant protocol for the current review update (in English) is being finalized and will soon be published here on OSF prior to restarting the review activities.

q2.value:
Consistent with previous research demonstrating that following normative timelines in romantic relationships is associated with higher relationship quality (Keneski, 2016), I predict that positive affect (H1) and relationship satisfaction (H2) will be rated as higher in the conditions when the behaviour matches the relationship length than when the behaviour does not match the relationship length, with the largest differences when the behaviour is early compared to matching. In contrast, I predict that negative affect (H3) and the likelihood of breakup (H4) will be rated as higher in the conditions when the behaviour does not match the relationship length than when the behaviour matches the relationship length, with the largest differences when the behaviour is early compared to matching.

These hypotheses apply specifically to the person who is being asked to engage in the novel behaviour (i.e. "Sam" in the vignettes), rather than the person initiating the novel behaviour (i.e. "Avery"). However, I will also explore whether perceptions of Avery's experiences vary by condition.

I will also explore whether these effects vary based on whether the novel behaviour being initiated is sexual or nonsexual in nature.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study is a cross-sectional, 2 (Behaviour: sexual vs. nonsexual) x 2 (Relationship length: 6 months vs. 3 years) x 2 (Behaviour timeline: 6 months vs. 3 years) between-subjects design.

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to condition using a randomizer in the survey software Qualtrics.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: At the time of registration, the data have been collected but has not been accessed from the survey software. Therefore, there has been no observation of the data at the time of registration.

question.value: Participants will be recruited from Prolific, an online crowdsourcing platform that is commonly used for psychological research. An advertisement will be placed on the Prolific website for Prolific users who meet the inclusion criteria, with information about the study as well as a link to the survey. Participants will be required to be at least 18 years of age, have an active Prolific account with at least 97% approval from at least 10 previous studies they have participated, live in the UK, USA or Canada, and be fluent in English. Eligible and interested participants will follow the link, and will be redirected to a survey hosted on Qualtrics, where the letter of information and consent will be presented. Informed consent will be received from each participant digitally (each participant must indicate they read the consent form and agree to take part before proceeding). Participants included in the final sample must correctly answer 1 attention check and 1 captcha, in addition to meeting all inclusion criteria.

q11.value: The target sample size for this study is approximately 800 individuals.

q12.value: A power analysis indicated that a sample size of 787 would be needed to find a statistically significant interaction in a 2 (relationship length: short vs. long) × 2 (typical behaviour incorporation: early vs. late) x 2 (type of behaviour: sexual vs. nonsexual) ANOVA assuming a small effect size (f = 0.10) with a power level of 0.80 (power estimated using GPower 3.1; Erdfelder et al., 1996; Faul et al., 2007). I will oversample slightly to account for loss of data due to not meeting the attention check, resulting in a target sample of 800 individuals.

question.value: I will run an experiment that provides participants with a hypothetical romantic couple where one partner is planning to initiate a novel behaviour with the other, and ask participants to imagine how each partner would feel. The length of time the couple has been together will vary by condition, as well as the novel activity that will be presented so that it is either one that is typical to engage in for the first time given their relationship length, or it is one that is typically engaged in at an earlier or later time for the first time, in addition to being either a sexual or nonsexual novel behaviour, creating eight conditions: matching at 6 months (sexual behaviour), matching at 3 years (sexual behaviour), sexual behaviour is early (3 year sexual behaviour in the 6 month relationship), sexual behaviour is late (6 month sexual behaviour in the 3 year relationship), matching at 6 months (nonsexual behaviour), matching at 3 years (nonsexual behaviour), nonsexual behaviour is early (3 year nonsexual behaviour in the 6 month relationship), or nonsexual behaviour is late (6 month nonsexual behaviour in the 3 year relationship).

Positive and negative affect. The Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS: Watson et al., 1988) is a 20-item scale that asks participants to respond to positive (10 items) and negative (10 items) mood adjectives on a 5-point scale (1 = Very slightly or not at all, 5 = Extremely). Only items that apply to the hypothetical scenario (e.g. nervous, distressed, interested, enthusiastic, etc.) will be used in the final positive and negative affect scores. Other items that do not apply to the scenario (e.g. alert, inspired, ashamed, guilty, etc.) will not be used in analyses. 
Relationship satisfaction. Three items adapted from the Investment Model Scale (“Sam and Avery’s relationship is much better than others’ relationships”, “Sam feels satisfied with their relationship”, “Their relationship makes Sam happy”; Rusbult et al., 1998) will be used to measure relationship satisfaction. Possible responses will be on a 9-point scale (1 = Do not agree at all, 9 = Agree completely). 
Likelihood of breakup. Participants’ perceptions of how likely it is that Sam and Avery will break up will be assessed with two items adapted from those used by Kelmer, Rhoades, Stanley, and Markman (2013; “How likely is it that Sam and Avery will break up within the next year?”, “How likely is it that Sam and Avery will get married?”). Possible responses will be on a 5-point scale (1 = Very unlikely, 5 = Very likely).
Scores from relevant items in the associated scales will be averaged to create overall scores for positive affect, negative affect, relationship satisfaction, and likelihood of breakup.

I will conduct a series of 2 (Behaviour: sexual vs. nonsexual) x 2 (Relationship length: 6 months vs. 3 years) x 2 (Behaviour timeline: 6 months vs. 3 years) ANOVAs predicting positive affect, negative affect, relationship satisfaction, and likelihood of breakup. To be conservative, all simple main effects associated with these ANOVAs will use Bonferroni adjustments.

q19.value: I will adjust my critical p-value based on the number of tests being conducted (4 confirmatory and 3 exploratory tests, p = .05/7 = .007).To be conservative, all simple main effects associated with these ANOVAs will also use Bonferroni adjustments.

q20.value: Participants included in the final sample must correctly answer 1 attention check and 1 captcha, in addition to meeting all inclusion criteria.

q21.value: Pairwise deletion will be used when calculating the scores for the outcome variables (i.e. creating an average score for each case using the data available, as long as at least 1 item was responded to for that specific scale).

q22.value:
I will explore whether perceptions of Avery's experiences (the initiator) vary by condition.

I will also explore whether these effects vary based on whether the novel behaviour being initiated is sexual or nonsexual in nature.

registration_responses.q10.question: Participants will be recruited from Prolific, an online crowdsourcing platform that is commonly used for psychological research. An advertisement will be placed on the Prolific website for Prolific users who meet the inclusion criteria, with information about the study as well as a link to the survey. Participants will be required to be at least 18 years of age, have an active Prolific account with at least 97% approval from at least 10 previous studies they have participated, live in the UK, USA or Canada, and be fluent in English. Eligible and interested participants will follow the link, and will be redirected to a survey hosted on Qualtrics, where the letter of information and consent will be presented. registration_responses.q14.question: I will run an experiment that provides participants with a hypothetical romantic couple where one partner is planning to initiate a novel behaviour with the other, and ask participants to imagine how each partner would feel. The length of time the couple has been together will vary by condition, as well as the novel activity that will be presented so that it is either one that is typical to engage in for the first time given their relationship length, or it is one that is typically engaged in at an earlier or later time for the first time, in addition to being either a sexual or nonsexual novel behaviour, creating eight conditions: matching at 6 months (sexual behaviour), matching at 3 years (sexual behaviour), sexual behaviour is early (3 year sexual behaviour in the 6 month relationship), sexual behaviour is late (6 month sexual behaviour in the 3 year relationship), matching at 6 months (nonsexual behaviour), matching at 3 years (nonsexual behaviour), nonsexual behaviour is early (3 year nonsexual behaviour in the 6 month relationship), or nonsexual behaviour is late (6 month nonsexual behaviour in the 3 year relationship).
registration_responses.q15.question:
Positive and negative affect. The Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS: Watson et al., 1988) is a 20-item scale that asks participants to respond to positive (10 items) and negative (10 items) mood adjectives on a 5-point scale (1 = Very slightly or not at all, 5 = Extremely). Only items that apply to the hypothetical scenario (e.g. nervous, distressed, interested, enthusiastic, etc.) will be used in the final positive and negative affect scores. Other items that do not apply to the scenario (e.g. alert, inspired, ashamed, guilty, etc.) will not be used in analyses. 
Relationship satisfaction. Three items adapted from the Investment Model Scale (“Sam and Avery’s relationship is much better than others’ relationships”, “Sam feels satisfied with their relationship”, “Their relationship makes Sam happy”; Rusbult et al., 1998) will be used to measure relationship satisfaction. Possible responses will be on a 9-point scale (1 = Do not agree at all, 9 = Agree completely). 
Likelihood of breakup. Participants’ perceptions of how likely it is that Sam and Avery will break up will be assessed with two items adapted from those used by Kelmer, Rhoades, Stanley, and Markman (2013; “How likely is it that Sam and Avery will break up within the next year?”, “How likely is it that Sam and Avery will get married?”). Possible responses will be on a 5-point scale (1 = Very unlikely, 5 = Very likely).
registration_responses.q16.question: Scores from relevant items in the associated scales will be averaged to create overall scores for positive affect, negative affect, relationship satisfaction, and likelihood of breakup.
registration_responses.q17.question: I will conduct a series of 2 (Behaviour: sexual vs. nonsexual) x 2 (Relationship length: 6 months vs. 3 years) x 2 (Behaviour timeline: 6 months vs. 3 years) ANOVAs predicting positive affect, negative affect, relationship satisfaction, and likelihood of breakup. To be conservative, all simple main effects associated with these ANOVAs will use Bonferroni adjustments.

attributes.title: Study 3
attributes.description: This study premised on the idea that although novelty is typically associated with relationship benefits, when you choose to incorporate new behaviours into the relationship likely impacts how beneficial it is, as incorporating new behaviours outside of the typical trajectory of relationship events could be perceived as threatening to one’s partner. In particular, I will run an experiment that provides participants with a hypothetical romantic couple where one partner is planning to initiate a novel behaviour with the other, and ask participants to imagine how each partner would feel. The length of time the couple has been together will vary by condition, as well as the novel activity that will be presented so that it is either one that is typical to engage in for the first time given their relationship length, or it is one that is typically engaged in at an earlier or later time for the first time, in addition to being either a sexual or nonsexual novel behaviour, creating eight experimental conditions.

q2.value:
Consistent with previous research demonstrating that following normative timelines in romantic relationships is associated with higher relationship quality (Keneski, 2016), I predict that positive affect (H1) and relationship satisfaction (H2) will be rated as higher in the conditions when the behaviour matches the relationship length than when the behaviour does not match the relationship length, with the largest differences when the behaviour is early compared to matching. In contrast, I predict that negative affect (H3) and the likelihood of breakup (H4) will be rated as higher in the conditions when the behaviour does not match the relationship length than when the behaviour matches the relationship length, with the largest differences when the behaviour is early compared to matching.

These hypotheses apply specifically to the person who is being asked to engage in the novel behaviour (i.e. "Sam" in the vignettes), rather than the person initiating the novel behaviour (i.e. "Avery"). However, I will also explore whether perceptions of Avery's experiences vary by condition.

I will also explore whether these effects vary based on whether the novel behaviour being initiated is sexual or nonsexual in nature.

1. The man in the picture below says, "I always drink Guinness it has a smooth taste that is also refreshing". Based on the advertisement how would you rate the attractiveness of the alcoholic product?

2. Will Smith in the picture below says, "I always drink Guinness it has a smooth taste that is also refreshing". Based on the advertisement phrase and photo below how would you rate the attractiveness of the alcoholic product?

IV: Age Groups
DV: Attractiveness of the alcohol product
I will be creating the two age groups by splitting them at the medium age.
ANOVA to test for interactions between age groups and advertisement types
